title: Opening of the Canadian parliament
text:
The opening of the Canadian parliament is the commencement of a session of the <a href="Parliament%20of%20Canada">Parliament of Canada</a> following a general election. It involves summons from the <a href="Governor%20General%20of%20Canada">governor general</a> on behalf of the <a href="Monarchy%20of%20Canada">monarch</a> and a ceremony based on the <a href="State%20Opening%20of%20Parliament">same in the United Kingdom</a>, though less elaborate and now evolved to include uniquely Canadian elements.
Summons.
At the same time as the <a href="Governor%20General%20of%20Canada">Governor General of Canada</a> <a href="Dropping%20the%20writ">drops the writ</a> for a <a href="Elections%20in%20Canada%23National%20elections">federal election</a>, he or she also issues a <a href="royal%20proclamation">royal proclamation</a> summoning parliament—setting the date for the opening of the next parliament following the election (though, the date may be amended by subsequent proclamations, so long as parliament eventually meets as required by the <a href="Constitution%20Act%2C%201867">Constitution Act, 1867</a>). Of the <a href="Deputy%20of%20the%20Governor%20General%20of%20Canada">governor general's deputies</a>, only the justices of the <a href="Supreme%20Court%20of%20Canada">supreme court</a> can summon parliament (though they, like the other deputies, may not dissolve it).
Opening of parliament.
Canada has two types of opening for the federal parliament, differentiated by scale: Larger openings, called "bench openings", require the seating of the <a href="Senate%20of%20Canada">Senate</a> (where the monarch, governor general, or another delegate reads the <a href="Speech%20from%20the%20throne">Throne Speech</a>), which is rearranged to accommodate the number of official guests—the justices of the <a href="Supreme%20Court%20of%20Canada">supreme court</a>, <a href="Lieutenant%20governor%20%28Canada%29">lieutenant-governors</a>, former prime ministers, members of the <a href="Queen%27s%20Privy%20Council%20for%20Canada">Queen's Privy Council for Canada</a>, and members of the diplomatic corps, and any spouses—and the galleries are reserved for other guests. Smaller openings, called "desk openings" do not require the removal of senators' desks, as guests are limited to the justices of the supreme court, invitees of the governor general and prime minister, and the deans of the diplomatic corps. The <a href="Speaker%20of%20the%20Senate%20of%20Canada">Speaker of the Senate</a> establishes the guest list, though the size of the ceremony is determined by the prime minister.
The opening of the first session of a parliament takes place over two days (the opening of a subsequent session of the same parliament requires only one day). On the first, routine business is conducted. After such is concluded, the Speaker of the Senate commands the <a href="Usher%20of%20the%20Black%20Rod%20%28Canada%29">Usher of the Black Rod</a> (usually called simply Black Rod) to summon the members of the House of Commons to the Senate. Once assembled, the speaker addresses the congregation, stating "Honourable Members of the Senate, Members of the House of Commons: I have it in command to let you know His [or Her] Excellency the Governor General does not see fit to declare the causes of his [or her] summoning of the present Parliament of Canada, until a Speaker of the House of Commons shall have been chosen, according to law; but tomorrow, [date], at [time], His [or Her] Excellency will declare the causes of his [or her] calling this parliament." The <a href="Member%20of%20Parliament">Members of Parliament</a> then return to the commons to elect the <a href="Speaker%20of%20the%20House%20of%20Commons%20%28Canada%29">speaker for that chamber</a>. The speech itself is delivered the following day.
As the Queen's representative, the governor general attends parliament to deliver the <a href="Speech%20From%20the%20Throne">Speech From the Throne</a>, although this can and has been done by the sovereign themselves or another representative, for example the Queen gave the Speech from the Throne in 1977. Accompanied by four officers of the <a href="Royal%20Canadian%20Mounted%20Police">Royal Canadian Mounted Police</a>, he or she usually rides in the <a href="Royal%20and%20viceroyal%20transport%20in%20Canada%23Carriage%20and%20automobile">State Landau</a>, often accompanied by the <a href="Viceregal%20consort%20of%20Canada">viceregal consort</a>, between <a href="Rideau%20Hall">Rideau Hall</a> and <a href="Parliament%20Hill">Parliament Hill</a>, where the governor general inspects a <a href="Canadian%20Armed%20Forces">Canadian Armed Forces</a> <a href="Guard%20of%20honour%23Canada">guard of honour</a>. Once the viceroy is in the parliament building, the Usher of the Black Rod is again sent to call the members of the House of Commons to the Senate. Upon his or her arrival at the bar of the Senate, the Speaker of the House of Commons addresses his counterpart in the Senate, asserting the rights and privileges of the commons and its members. The Speaker of the Senate, on behalf of the governor general, responds that the Crown will "recognise and allow their constitutional privileges". The governor general then reads the Throne Speech, during which the Senate's mace is held by the Mace Bearer, who stands to the side of the throne.
Debate.
The address is followed by a debate and vote in both houses of parliament. Formally, the motion merely calls on parliament to thank the monarch or viceroy for the speech via an Address in Reply. Until 1897, this was a more detailed message, covering the content of the Throne Speech point by point. Today, in the Senate, takes the form of simply:
The debate is, however, often wide-ranging, exploring many aspects of the government's proposed policies, and spread over several days. When the Address in Reply is eventually voted on, the poll is held to constitute a <a href="Motion%20of%20no%20confidence">motion of confidence</a> in the government, which, if lost, would result in the end of that government's mandate. This discussion and vote follows a symbolic raising of other matters, designed to highlight the independence of parliament from the Crown; a practice that originated after <a href="Charles%20I%20of%20England">King Charles I</a> was tried and executed by the <a href="Parliament%20of%20England">Parliament of England</a>. In the Senate, it is <a href="Bills%20C-1%20and%20S-1">Bill S-1</a>, an Act Relating to Railways.
